definition: Anterior pituitary peptide from POMC that stimulates the adrenal cortex (zona fasciculata/reticularis) to make cortisol (and adrenal androgens).
why_it_matters: It’s the switch that separates adrenal from pituitary/ectopic causes of hypercortisolism and explains steroid‑induced adrenal suppression.
how_youll_see_it: Diurnal: high in early morning, low at night
problem_solving: Suspected hypercortisolism: 1) low‑dose dex suppression OR late‑night salivary cortisol OR 24‑hr urinary free cortisol
↑ACTH? → High‑dose dex suppression: pituitary disease tends to suppress; ectopic does not
Low/undetectable ACTH? → adrenal source or exogenous steroid use

differentials.name: Cushing disease
differentials.hint: Pituitary ACTH; often suppresses with high‑dose dex

differentials: Primary adrenal insufficiency — low cortisol with high ACTH + hyperpigmentation
Secondary adrenal insufficiency — low cortisol and low ACTH; normal potassium
tricks: Exogenous steroids → low ACTH and adrenal atrophy; taper slowly to avoid crisis
Hyperpigmentation happens only when ACTH is high (POMC → MSH peptides)
ACTH has a short half‑life; draw with cortisol in the morning when possible
exam_appearance: Pituitary macroadenoma + Cushingoid features; high‑dose dex suppresses cortisol
Smoker with weight loss + severe hypokalemia; no suppression with high‑dose dex → ectopic ACTH
Long‑term prednisone stopped abruptly → hypotension, nausea, **low ACTH & cortisol**
treatment: Cushing disease — transsphenoidal resection; medical therapy if not surgical candidate (ketoconazole, metyrapone)
Ectopic ACTH — treat the tumor; temporary cortisol blockade if needed
Secondary adrenal insufficiency — physiologic glucocorticoid replacement; stress‑dose steroids when ill
Never stop chronic steroids abruptly; taper
red_flags: Adrenal crisis: hypotension, vomiting, abdominal pain — give IV hydrocortisone immediately
Severe hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis in ectopic ACTH
algorithm: Confirm hypercortisolism with one reliable test.
High ACTH → high‑dose dex suppression ± CRH test → pituitary vs ectopic.
Low ACTH → adrenal imaging or steroid history.
Treat cause; manage comorbidities and bone protection.

cases.stem: 52‑year‑old with facial rounding, purple striae, new hypertension.
cases.teaching: High ACTH + suppression with high‑dose dex → pituitary source.

cases.stem: 65‑year‑old smoker with rapid‑onset weakness and weight loss.
cases.teaching: Hypokalemia is a clue to ectopic ACTH (mineralocorticoid effect of very high cortisol).
